history.content:
Seems like you have good odds of getting 16A, but the others seem pretty unlikely. That is a huge waitlist for 170, and since 162 is normally about 1/3 the size of 170 #88th is pretty far back on the waitlist too. Unforntunately if you are not declared (and in many cases even if you are) you are very unlikely to get into any upper divs. You will likely have to take summer classes to complete your degree on time. 

Not true, I think you have a decent chance. You will basically remain waitlisted until the you declare CS, after which you get access to the seats reserved for CS Majors. CS 170 and CS 162 are typically classes that expand to take everyone off the waitlist, too. And even if you can't get into those specific courses, there are plenty of other CS upper divs that will have open seats. For example, CS 188 for next semester currently has 400+ open seats that are reserved for CS majors.

Even if you can't get into any CS upper divs (the probability of which is very small), you can also look at upper division classes in other departments that could work towards your 7 units technical breadth requirement. There are so so so many options for that. 

You can almost certainly graduate on time without having to take summer classes, considering that you are already looking at enrolling in upper divisions in your second semester here.

Seems like you have good odds of getting 16A, but the others seem pretty unlikely. That is a huge waitlist for 170, and since 162 is normally about 1/3 the size of 170 #88th is pretty far back on the waitlist too. Unforntunately if you are not declared (and in many cases even if you are) you are very unlikely to get into any upper divs. You will likely have to take summer classes to complete your degree on time

children.subject:
Thanks -- yours and the student's comment put my mind at ease. I was freaking out over not being able to graduate and formulating plans as if I would not be able to take those courses next semester haha..

Apparently 36 upper division units is needed to graduate L&S and I haven't finished a single one yet which is why I'm rushing trying to take upper divs by declaring CS/finishing 61C this semester. I think this makes me need to take 3 upper divs per semester until I graduate. I definitely wouldn't want to fit all those units my last year.

I was EECS - and I only need to take 5 upper division classes to graduate (in addition to ethics, 2 H/SS, AC). I know requirements slightly different between the colleges, but I would definitely contact a counselor to make sure what is the required workload and if you can get a 5th semester. 3 upper divs every semester after the first one sound extremely harsh to me. 
Good luck!!

Holy smokes, 162 on your second semester at cal (along with 170)? I was a transfer a few years ago and took 3 techs each semester, and this looks brutal even for me. Have you taken 61C yet? I’d consider it really important for 162.

Regardless of that, don’t worry about graduating. Everyone who transfers to cal can graduate without taking *too* much load, and the department is rather flexible.

history.content:
I'm a first semester L&S transfer intending on declaring CS. I'm declaring the end of the semester.

I signed up for some upper divs for next semester and phase 1'd 162 (#88), 16A (#46), 170 (#236) where I'm waitlisted in all of them because I'm not a CS declared. Are my chances good for these upper divs? What do I take if I don't get into these courses? I finished my breadths prior to transferring.

I have three semesters left at Cal and I'm worried I might not be able to graduate on time. Are there any other LSCS transfers that are/have been in the same situation?
history.subject: Waitlisted for all my classes (LSCS Transfer)
